did.head: Descriptive Summary
did.unittitle: Northumberland County (Va.) Chancery Cause, Margaret B. Hudnall, etc vs. Nancy Waddy, etc, 1820

userestrict.head: Use Restrictions
userestrict.p: Patrons are to use digital images of Northumberland County (Va.) Chancery Causes found on the Chancery Records Index available electronically at the website of the Library of Virginia.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Northumberland County (Va.) Chancery Cause, Margaret B. Hudnall, etc vs. Nancy Waddy, etc, 1820. Local government records collection, Northumberland County Court Records. The Library of Virginia, Richmond, Va. 23219.

acqinfo.head: Acquisition Information
acqinfo.p: These items came to the Library of Virginia in a transfer of court papers from Northumberland County under the accession number 43283.

bioghist.head: Historical Information
bioghist.p: In 1809, William Day sent Molly Waddy then living in Northumberland County near Smith Point Light House two letters. The correspondence described to Mrs. Waddy how her son, an American sailor named Alexander, had been taken from his ship and impressed into the British navy. Although Alexander later managed to escape from British service, he died before reaching the United States.

These were used as an exhibit in a chancery suit instituted several years later by Alexander's sister. In order to claim her brother's portion of an inheritance, Margaret C. Hudnall produced the two letters to prove Alexander had died.

Chancery Causes are cases of equity. According to Black's Law Dictionary they are "administered according to fairness as contrasted with the strictly formulated rules of common law." A judge, not a jury, determines the outcome of the case.

Northumberland County probably was named for the English county. It was formed about 1645 from the district of Chickacoan, the early-seventeenth-century name for the region between the Potomac and the Rappahannock rivers.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: Northumberland County (Va.) Chancery Cause, Margaret B. Hudnall, etc vs. Nancy Waddy, etc, 1820, contains two letters that describe the impressment of Alexander Waddy into the British Navy and his manner of death.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Material
relatedmaterial.p: Additional Northumberland Court Records can be found on microfilm at The Library of Virginia web site. Consult "A Guide to Virginia County and City Records on Microfilm."
See The Chancery Records Index to search for chancery suits of Northumberland and additional Virginia localities.
